question.title: io.grpc.StatusRuntimeException: UNAVAILABLE: io exception with firestore
question.body:
I have a simple Micronaut application with controller as below

import com.google.api.core.ApiFuture;
import com.google.auth.oauth2.GoogleCredentials;
import com.google.cloud.firestore.*;
import io.micronaut.http.annotation.*;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException;

@Controller("/ms-office")
public class MsOfficeController {

    @Get(uri = "/", produces = "text/plain")
    public String index() throws IOException, ExecutionException, InterruptedException {
        FirestoreOptions firestoreOptions =
                FirestoreOptions.getDefaultInstance().toBuilder()
                        .setProjectId("prj-wrk-genai-sandbox-sken")
                        .setCredentials(GoogleCredentials.getApplicationDefault())
                        .build();
        Firestore db = firestoreOptions.getService();

        // asynchronously retrieve all users
        ApiFuture<QuerySnapshot> query = db.collection("companionplus").get();
        // ...
        // query.get() blocks on response
        QuerySnapshot querySnapshot = query.get();
        List<QueryDocumentSnapshot> documents = querySnapshot.getDocuments();
        for (QueryDocumentSnapshot document : documents) {
            System.out.println("User: " + document.getId());
            System.out.println("First: " + document.getString("first"));
            if (document.contains("middle")) {
                System.out.println("Middle: " + document.getString("middle"));
            }
            System.out.println("Last: " + document.getString("last"));
            System.out.println("Born: " + document.getLong("born"));
        }

        return "Example Response";
    }

Facing an error as below

ERROR i.m.http.server.RouteExecutor - Unexpected error occurred: io.grpc.StatusRuntimeException: UNAVAILABLE: io exception
Channel Pipeline: [SslHandler#0, ProtocolNegotiators$ClientTlsHandler#0, WriteBufferingAndExceptionHandler#0, DefaultChannelPipeline$TailContext#0]

Disconnected from the target VM, address: '127.0.0.1:59940', transport: 'socket'
20:13:28.216 [Thread-0] INFO  io.micronaut.runtime.Micronaut - Embedded Application shutting down

Process finished with exit code 130

I am on windows machine and login to the app as below

Update

After adding the certificate to the jdk as below

.\keytool.exe -import -alias "googlecloud" -keystore "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk-21\lib\security\cacerts" -file "C:\Users\jaisya\Downloads\googlecloud.crt"

answers.body:
For the first set of errors you’re facing, there seems to be no issue on Firestore side (which is less likely). I also agree with DazWilkin that the issue appears to be related to Java's use of certificates via the sun.security.provider.certpath package. Those errors might occur when Java (through the Java Virtual Machine or JVM) tries to establish a secure connection using SSL but fails because it can't find a valid certification path. In other words, this error is a Java error that is both related to a certification path issue and an SSL handshake issue (since the path issue actually causes the handshake issue).

The SSLHandshakeException Authentication error also occurs when the 'JVM keystore' isn't utilizing all Root CAs in the roots.pem file when asked to present a Valid Cert. The authentication fails until the GTS Root R1 certificate is issued on the machine. I think Java only trusts certificates that are signed by those within its 'truststore,' which is likely stored in a directory similar to ../jre/lib/security, based on my understanding.

Regarding possible fixes, I explored other resources and found some workarounds that might be able to help you resolve the issue, which I will share below.

  • Try to verify which certificate is being presented via openssl or keytool.

  • See this FAQ from Google Trust Services (GTS), which includes a section titled 'I'm building or using a product that connects to Google services. What CA certificates do I need to trust?’ – this might be helpful for you.

  • It is mentioned here that the problem may appear when the server has a self signed certificate that wasn’t added to the list of trusted certificates (the cacerts file) of the Java Virtual Machine. It is also mentioned that you could have both ‘jre’ & ‘jdk’, and if so, both you need their ‘cacerts’ updated.

  • Some suggestions were given here for a situation involving a corporate network that had its own certificates and security rules.

As for the second error you're encountering, it seems your application can't establish a network connection to firestore.googleapis.com. You may have a restriction on your end that is blocking you, such as a firewall, VPN, proxy server, corporate network, or another network configuration. I recommend conducting a network connectivity test.

  • Try to ping firestore.googleapis.com from your machine. If it fails, the problem is outside your application.

  • Try to temporarily disable antivirus (if safe and only for testing) as they can sometimes interfere with network connections.

  • Check your firewall for outbound blocking rules.

question_comments.body: @DazWilkin Google's Firestore certs how to get this ??? Also I am facing the new issue after the cert install, updated in the new section as UPDATED. I did it just navigating to cloud.google then export the cert from the browser

This is the key issue: SunCertPathBuilderException: unable to find valid certification path to requested target. Are you on a corporate network? Behind a proxy? I suspect (!?) that the corporate firewall is intercepting the certificate request. If so, you'll need to trust your corporate certs. Very unlikely: there's an issue with Google's Firestore certs.
